sect2.title: How can I stop fsck on my vfat filesystem?
sect2.para: If you want to prevent fsck from checking Windows (vfat) partitions on boot (sometimes this seems to cause many error messages), then edit /etc/fstab and change the pass argument (6th column) to 0.

sect2.title: How can I configure the system so that when I open a folder, its contents are displayed in the existing window rather than opening a new window (disabling "spatial" mode)?
sect2.para: Open Computer->Desktop Preferences->File Management, select the Behavior tab, and check the box next to "Always open in browser windows".

The new "spatial view" of Gnome may take a little getting used to but some people liked it after a while. Try it out before you disable it. You can still click on folders with the middle mouse-button and get the subfolder displayed in the same window.

sect2.title: What is the simplest way to install the development tools so that I can compile programs?
sect2.para: sudo aptitude install build-essential
Development tools are included on the CD, and so do not need to be downloaded.

sect2.title: Once I have installed Ubuntu, will I be able to upgrade to the next release?
sect2.para: Yes.

We fully support upgrades from one release to the next. For example, if you installed WartyWarthog, you will be able to upgrade to HoaryHedgehog when it is released, and from HoaryHedgehog to GrumpyGroundhog, and so forth in perpetuity.
Note that this does not necessarily extend to certain situations involving unsupported software, such as packages in the universe repository, or software which you obtained from a third-party source.

sect2.title: I am trying to set up an NFS server. I think I've done everything right, but it doesn't seem to work. I get an error "mount: RPC: Remote system error - Connection refused". What have I missed?
sect2.para: By default, the portmap daemon listens only on the loopback interface (localhost). You can change this by editing /etc/default/portmap and removing the "-i 127.0.0.1" option from the command line arguments.

sect2.title: How can I install software development tools?
sect2.para: A default Ubuntu desktop installation includes a full-featured Python development environment, so if you want to develop in Python, you should already have everything you need.
If you want to develop in C or C++, install the build-essential package.

The choice to exclude C/C++ development tools from the default desktop install was an explicit one. The discussion is archived here: http://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/sounder/2004-September/000524.html

sect2.title: How do I change the Splash Screen image for all users?
sect2.para: To change the splash image for everybody on your system who hasn't changed it themselves:

itemizedlist.listitem: applications -> Run application
gksudo gconf-editor
File -> New Defaults Window
Choose /applications/gnome-session/options from the tree on the left
Change the splash_image key to (e.g.) splash/ubuntu-logo-508x340.png

sect2.para: Alternatively, you can use this in a script:

itemizedlist.listitem: Become root

Run the following command:
gconftool-2 --direct --config-source=xml:readwrite:/etc/gconf/gconf.xml.defaults --type string --set applications/gnome-session/options/splash_image splash/splash_image.png)

sect2.title: How do I change the default desktop background image for everyone?

itemizedlist.listitem: applications -> Run application

Enter your password if prompted
File -> New Defaults Window
Choose /desktop/gnome/background from the tree on the left
Change the picture_filename key to (e.g.) /usr/share/backgrounds/ubuntu-calendar.png

sect2.title: How do I customize the applications menu?
sect2.para: You can edit existing submenus under applications by right-clicking in the menu. For example, here's how to add an entry to the Games menu:

itemizedlist.listitem: Select applications -> Games, and right-click in the menu.

Select Entire Menu -> Add new item to this menu.
In the window that applicationears, enter the name that you want to applicationear in the menu in the Name field, and enter the executable command in the Command field.
Click OK.

sect2.para: To edit the applications menu itself requires a few more steps.

itemizedlist.listitem: Start Nautilus (e.g. select Computer -> Home).

In Nautilus, press ctrl-L, type applications:/// in the Location field, and hit Enter. (As you type, the label will occasionally change to Go to:.) This will show a list of the menu entries with their icons.

sect2.para: To add a program to the menu, right-click in Nautilus, select Create Launcher, and fill in the fields. Name is the name that will applicationear in the menu, and Command is the actual command that will be executed when the menu item is selected. Click on OK to update the menu.

To add a submenu to applications, right-click in Nautilus and select Create Folder. The name of this new folder will become the entry in the applications menu. Then double-click on the new folder, and start adding launchers.
To change the applications menu for all users, go to applications-all-users:/// in Nautilus. You will need root privileges to change this.
Note: You can not customize the Computer menu.

sect2.title: How can I share my printer on my LAN?
sect2.para: Ubuntu's default installation of CUPS only listens for local IPP connections. At the present time you have to edit /etc/cups/cupsd.conf to make it available to other machines on your LAN. There are two things that must be changed:

itemizedlist.listitem: A line that has Listen 127.0.0.1:631 can be replaced by Port 631 to listen on all network interfaces, or, if you have a more complex setup and don't want to listen on all interfaces,you can add additional Listen lines for each IP address that you want it to hear.

There is a group of lines that further limit what listened-to traffic will be processed. By default it only allows internal loopback (that's the 127.0.0.1 address). You can add individual IP addresses in addition Allow lines, or whole blocks such as a typical router's internal network with 192.168.1.*. With the latter added, the block looks like

sect2.screen: Order Deny,Allow Deny From All Allow From 127.0.0.1 Allow From 192.168.1.*

itemizedlist.listitem: If you are going to print from Windows 98 or Windows 95 you'll need additional software from Microsoft in your Windows box.
The page NetworkPrintingFromWin2K contains some notes on setting up an Ubuntu printer in Windows 2000.
